newsitem.title: GREECE: Karamanlis voted head of Greek conservative party.
newsitem.headline: Karamanlis voted head of Greek conservative party.

text.p: Costas Karamanlis, nephew of Greek elder statesman Constantine Karamanlis, was elected on Friday new leader of the main conservative opposition New Democracy party with the hard task to unite it.
Karamanlis, 40, won 2,350 votes to the 1,048 garnered by hios closest challenger, former economy minister George Souflias, at a party congress.
Karamanlis is a lawyer and party deputy from the northern port city of Salonika. A quiet backbencher, he has never held government office nor expressed any political ambition until earlier this year.
New Democracy is badly divided and disoriented following an election loss last September to the ruling PASOK socialist party of Prime Minister Costas Simitis.

The party was founded by Constantine Karamanlis in 1974 after the fall of a seven-year dictatorship. He won two four-year terms during which he led Greece into the European Union and then moved on to become state president.
"The younger Karamanlis is riding on his uncle's name," said Stelios Apostolakis, a party member at the congress. "But it will take more than a name to unite New Democracy and lead it to power."
Outgoing New Democracy president Miltiadis Evert was blamed for last year's election loss and came third in Friday's leadership vote behind Karamanlis and Souflias.
